urn:contentItem:5S1W-TF81-F149-S4SJ-00000-00The weird things that Facebook has on me2018-04-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:04ZLexisNexisPg. 23The weird things that Facebookhas on me

It is easy enough to find if you know where to look, discovers NICK WHIGHAM

IT WAS the first day of pre-school. After my Mum leaned down and gave me one final bear hug, I was off to start my education.

I don't remember this seminal moment, but I happened to stumble upon the footage this week by complete happenstance.

The video is of a TV screen playing an old VHS tape and appears to be taken on a camera phone. My guess is my younger sister found the tape and filmed the video to send to me.

But maybe I should just ask Facebook, because that's where I found it - in the huge file containing my extensive Facebookhistory the company keeps on me.

Since the moment I, and everyone else signed up, the social media service has been collecting and keeping everything - I seriously mean everything - we have ever done on the site. All the conversations, videos, pictures and documents we have shared or have had sent to us are all held on a server somewhere with space specially dedicated to each of us.

I downloaded the cache (it's very easy to do) to check out everything Mark Zuckerberg had on file about me from over the years.

It included scanned copies of lease forms from a previous rental property I must've sent to my buddies over Messenger, my current tenant ledger report, an old monthly billing statement for my home broadband, screen shots of banking transfers and seemingly endless web pages of all the banal conversations I have ever had on the platform.

It's one thing to know Facebookholds all this data (and much more) on you but it's another thing to trawl through it and find things even you'd forgotten about yourself.

It's an odd feeling to think that, in some ways, Facebookknows you better than you know yourself.

Looking through the 500MB zip file you can see your "Ads History" which stores what ads you've ever clicked on as well as all the advertisers who Facebookhas shared your contact information with.

It has facial recognition data (Facebookhas 105 examples of what I look like), exhaustive photo metadata including your location and the time the photo was taken and data about every time you logged onto the site such as the IP address, location, browser and device used.

My file also contained the names and numbers for everyone in my iPhone's contact list - and yours will too.

Facebooknot only knows everything you've ever done on its platform but via cookies it leaves in your web browser it also tracks you wherever you go on the internet "" even if you don't use Facebook.

I, like many others, opened my Facebookaccount just over a decade ago. Arguably it's the first time in history that 10 years of human behaviour has been meticulously gathered, stored and analysed by a company on this scale.

It's called surveillance capitalism and it's the reason why Mark Zuckerberg is worth $92 billion.

But as the public and regulators become increasingly aware of just how deep Facebook's tentacles extend into our digital lives, the company is facing increasing political headwinds.

Earlier this month Belgium ordered Facebookto stop tracking internet users who have no accounts with the social network, or face fines of 250,000 euros a day.

Now Australia has become the latest government to turn up the heat on the Zuckerbergs of the world.

The Federal Government has ordered the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) to investigate the big tech giants in what ACCC chairman Rodd Sims said will be the broadest inquiry of its type in the world.

The ACCC's inquiry will involve asking consumers how much they think the digital platforms know about them and comparing that to what is in fact being gathered.

"My suspicion is Facebookand Google have much more personal information about people than people realise," Mr Sims said.

urn:contentItem:5X92-4DR1-DYTY-C3F3-00000-00The Westminster politicians making a second home in Silicon Valley;Technology Intelligence ; From Clegg to Cameron, Big Tech is pulling in UK expertise, finds Olivia Rudgard in San Francisco2019-10-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:04ZLexisNexisBUSINESS;NEWSPg. 8The Westminster politicians making a second home in Silicon ValleyTechnology Intelligence ; From Clegg to Cameron, Big Tech is pulling in UK expertise, finds Olivia Rudgard in San FranciscoSan Francisco

Where do former mandarins go once Westminster has lost its shine? The private sector has always held temptations for civil servants and advisers, who head to consultancies and intelligence firms to enjoy higher salaries and more freedom away from the strictures of government.

But nowadays there's an even bigger prize - Silicon Valley. A succession of top Westminster policy figures have been drawn into the California tech scene, taking on roles at Google, Facebook, Uber and Netflix, and helping those companies navigate the growing regulatory scrutiny they face both in the US and abroad.

This challenge has lured Sir Nick Clegg, the former deputy prime minister, to Facebook and Rachel Whetstone, a former Conservative adviser, to Google, Facebook, Uber and finally to Netflix. Others have joined Twitter and Amazon following careers in Westminster and Brussels.

Former prime minister David Cameron is the chairman of Washington DC artificial intelligence company Afiniti's advisory board, and his one-time chancellor George Osborne has joined his brother's Silicon Valley venture capital firm. At lower levels, Silicon Valley companies' policy arms are stuffed with dozens of former Labour and Tory advisers and civil servants.

"We are asked for comms people from the US and policy people from Europe," says Dan Hyde, founder of executive search firm Erevena, which has placed multiple British policy experts in Silicon Valley.

Incoming policy experts fill a gap left by their existing communications and policy advisers, who are experts in corporate dealings but have less experience managing regulators.

US tech companies are "starting to come up against the regulatory aspects of policy," Hyde says. Much to Silicon Valley's chagrin, it has indeed become an inevitability. Washington, which has for many years been content to turn a blind eye to tech's West Coast money-printing machine, has suddenly begun to take notice.

Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook's chief executive, and Jack Dorsey, his Twitter counterpart, have both been hauled in front of senators in the past 18 months.

Silicon Valley's biggest companies are under pressure as they are accused of anti-competitive behaviour, damaging the democratic process and mismanaging the data of millions of users.

Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google face competition investigations from the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission, and attacks on the tech giants have become a regular rallying cry from the crop of would-be Democratic presidential candidates, such as Elizabeth Warren. Silicon Valley needs help negotiating these treacherous new waters, and it has turned to Westminster to get it.

But why Britons? British entrepreneurs are already common in the California tech scene, tempted away from London by the promise of bigger investments and proximity to billion-dollar companies.

There's also the fact that much of the pressure is coming from Europe.

The UK takes a more even-handed middle ground than the more draconian approach taken by no-nonsense EU regulators.

Andrew Whittaker, the UK's consul general in San Francisco, argues that British policy experts have experience balancing business-friendly policy with managing public pressure.

"From a government perspective, we're trying to get the balance right between being both innovation friendly, supporting businesses, and addressing legitimate concerns that our citizens raise, and people are used to doing that," he says.

Europe looks set to keep up the pressure it has been putting on Silicon Valley for half a decade. Margrethe Vestager, long a thorn in the side of US tech companies as competition commissioner, is expanding her power base to become a vice president of the European Commission.

Experience of Westminster's more open culture, where advisers mingle with journalists in the pub and brief them via text message, is also an asset for these new hires, who are joining some of the most secretive and controlling companies in the world.

Many of them hope to encourage their bosses to loosen up so they can try to improve the sector's poor reputation for transparency.

Nick Pickles, director of public policy strategy at Twitter, was previously director of Big Brother Watch in London, and before that ran as a Conservative parliamentary candidate in the north of England.

"You can hear echoes of previous debates in Europe and the UK in discussions around the world," he said. "Whether it's discussions about content regulation or privacy and surveillance, those have been on the table in Westminster or Brussels for some time and there are lessons from those debates that are relevant in the US and elsewhere."

For the emigrants, coastal California, with its redwood forests, big-wave surfing and dry, warm climate, is decent compensation.

A sizeable Silicon Valley salary, plus stock options, is likely to be a considerable step up even for someone coming from the most successful of Westminster careers.

Earlier this year it emerged that the Cleggs have bought a £7m home, with a hot tub and pool, in Atherton, San Mateo, crowned the most expensive postcode in the US by Forbes.

For Clegg, an arch-Remainer, being far, far away from the UK as Brexit rumbles on probably doesn't hurt either.

urn:contentItem:5RPF-FSP1-F105-64D7-00000-00The WeWork manifesto: First, office space. Next, the world.2018-02-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:04ZLexisNexisNEWSThe WeWork manifesto: First, office space. Next, the world.

NEW YORK - On a cold February morning at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the skeleton of a modern 15-storey building was rising from a muddy construction site along the East River. As long and as tall as a cruise ship, the sleek glass structure loomed above rusty, century-old dry docks, serving notice to the industrial neighbourhood that the new economy was coming.

The project, known as Dock 72, is the brainchild of WeWork, the fast-growing New York-based business own by an Israeli that is now valued at $20 billion. In just eight years, WeWork has built a network of 212 shared working spaces around the globe. But WeWork's chief executive and co-founder, Adam Neumann, isn't content to just lease out communal offices. Neumann - a lanky, longhaired 38-year-old - wants nothing less than to radically transform the way we work, live and play.

When Dock 72 is completed this year, if the aggressive timeline holds, it will represent the fullest expression of Neumann's expansive vision to date. There will be an enormous co-working space, a luxury spa and large offices, for other companies like IBM and Verizon, that are designed and run by WeWork. There will be a juice bar, a real bar, a gym with a boxing studio, an outdoor basketball court and panoramic vistas of Manhattan. There will be restaurants and maybe even dry cleaning services and a barbershop.

It will be the kind of place you never have to leave until you need to go to sleep - and if Neumann has his way, you'll sleep at one of the apartments he is renting nearby.

It's an all-encompassing sort of ambition, and Neumann is the brash and idealistic pitchman. Simply by encouraging strangers to share a beer at the office, he argues, WeWork can heal our fractured society.

"How do you change the world?" Neumann asked in a recent interview. "Bring people together. Where is the easiest big place to bring people together? In the work environment."

It may sound simplistic, but around the globe, companies are buying whatever it is that Neumann and his co-founder, Miguel McKelvey, are selling. WeWork has rapidly expanded to 20 countries - it offers work spaces in Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver - assembled a formidable executive team and attracted some 200,000 members. Big companies like JPMorgan Chase and Siemens are signing on as tenants, and revenues are growing fast, expected to top $2.3 billion this year.

WeWork last year bought the iconic Lord & Taylor building on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, which is being transformed into the company's new headquarters. That purchase from Canada's Hudson's Bay Co. was made possible in part by a recent $4.4 billion investment from Softbank, the Japanese technology group led by the enigmatic billionaire Masayoshi Son.

Already the company has started WeLive, its residential offering, and Rise, its gym. It acquired Meetup, a social network that facilitates in-person gatherings, and the Flatiron School, a coding academy. Still to come: WeGrow, the company's for-profit elementary school, set to open in September. WeWork has even invested in plans to create giant wave pools for inland surfing.

A company ostensibly about co-working now employs yoga instructors, architects, teachers, environmental scientists, software engineers, molecular biologists and social psychologists.

Is it all a bit much for a young company still trying to build out its core business? "I've made that argument," said Bruce Dunlevie, a WeWork board member and partner at the venture capital firm Benchmark. But, he said, "great entrepreneurs like Adam don't listen to guys like me."

As WeWork expands in all directions, it faces persistent questions about its rich valuation and the durability of its business model. Critics argue that the company does little more than corporate real estate arbitrage - leasing a space, spiffing it up, then subleasing it to other tenants. The company owns hardly any properties, giving it precious few hard assets. Its growth projections strike many as unattainable, and it has missed expectations before. A number of upstarts loom as potential competitors, seeking to replicate WeWork's success. And many WeWork tenants are unproven startups that could quickly fold.

IWG, a publicly traded co-working company that has more members and more real estate than WeWork, is valued at $2 billion. Yet Neumann has convinced investors that WeWork is worth 10 times that figure.

"Adam's explanation for the valuation of WeWork speaks for itself," said Chris Kelly, co-founder and president of Convene, a company that offers flexible event spaces and is backed by major real estate firms. "This is not an Excel spreadsheet calculation. He believes there's an energy behind the brand, and he's gotten people to invest at that valuation. He has not tried to explain it in traditional financial terms."

To assess WeWork by conventional metrics is to miss the point, according to Neumann. WeWork isn't really a real estate company. It's a state of consciousness, he argues, a generation of interconnected emotionally intelligent entrepreneurs. And Neumann, with his combination of inspiration and chutzpah, wants to transform not just the way we work and live but the very world we live in.

It's an audacious, perhaps delusional plan for a company that made its mark by building communal desks and providing refreshments. So far, it seems to be working.

Son, WeWork's largest investor, is betting that the company will grow exponentially in the years to come, making his multibillion-dollar investment a veritable bargain.

"Make it 10 times bigger than your original plan," Son told Forbes late last year. "If you think in that manner, the valuation is cheap. It can be worth a few hundred billion dollars."

Close Communities

The notion that white-collar workers might actually like their offices is a relatively new one. From the countinghouses of industrial England to the skyscrapers of 1980s Manhattan, offices were mostly uninspiring places designed to maximize space, often with row upon row of unglamorous desks.

"The only kind of model that anyone had for laying out a large workplace was a factory," said Nikil Saval, author of "Cubed: A Secret History of the Workplace." "So the office was made to resemble an assembly line."

This dreary state of affairs began to change in earnest, at least for some, during the dot-com bubble. Tech companies built playful offices with beanbags and Ping-Pong tables, making work spaces less formal. Free food became commonplace.

Raised expectations for amenities and interior design gradually seeped into the mainstream, and today, more and more employees - especially millennials - expect enlightened, unconventional offices.

Enter WeWork. With people bouncing between employers, jobs concentrated in cities and technology making it easier to work remotely, the demand for co-working was suddenly real and ready to be monetized. Neumann, who grew up on a kibbutz in Israel, had an epiphany: Bring the communal vibe to the office.

Soon he and a friend - McKelvey, an equally tall Oregonian who grew up on a collective and was working as an architect - founded an eco-friendly co-working space in Brooklyn. They sold it, but they quickly turned around and started WeWork in 2010.

"Me and Miguel have this common ground," Neumann said. "We both grew up in very close communities."

(END OPTIONAL TRIM.)

WeWork didn't invent co-working spaces, of course. IWG, better known as Regus, has been around for decades. But Neumann and McKelvey quickly hit upon a recipe that drew throngs of startups: an industrial chic esthetic, some big common areas with comfy couches, free beer and piped-in pop music.

Individuals pay as little as $45 a month for occasional access to a desk in a common area. Startups can pay a few thousand dollars for a private room on a month-to-month basis, and some big companies pay millions of dollars a year for spaces that hold thousands of employees over multiple locations.

It's a formula that has caught on from New York to Tel Aviv to Shanghai. In New York alone, WeWork has 49 spaces, most of them nearly full. At the WeWork in Harlem, dance companies share space with hair care startups in a common area adorned with murals of jazz musicians. At a WeWork in Tribeca, fashion designers and alcohol distributors work shoulder to shoulder in a spartan space decorated with neon lighting.

But for WeWork to really succeed in changing the way we all work, it is going to have to win over big corporations seeking space for thousands of employees. The strategy is an odd reversal for WeWork, which made its name catering to freelancers and startups.

The Weather Channel recently moved its ad sales team into an enormous WeWork in midtown Manhattan. Barbara Bekkedahl, who runs the group, said the transition was easy and the space comfortable and stylish.

But Bekkedahl had a complaint, too, one that highlights one of the downsides of communal work space. She suggested that the hygienic and sartorial habits of some of her new office mates were lacking.

"As a TV sales team, we groom and dress for outside sales," she said. "Some of the techie and startup types housed at WeWork aren't facing customers all day so don't always have the same standards."

Gripes about grooming are unlikely to slow down WeWork's business with corporate clients, especially if Neumann makes good on his promise to save them money. Because WeWork is building out so much space and buying so much furniture, Neumann says, he can renovate and operate an office for a fraction of the cost that companies would normally spend.

"We have economies of scale," he said. "I'll cut your operational costs between 20 to 50 per cent."

It might seem like another instance of Neumann's talking a big game but for the fact that more and more companies - GE, HSBC, Salesforce and Microsoft among them - are signing on.

For years now, big companies have outsourced payroll processing, janitorial services and security. It's not a stretch to imagine more of them outsourcing the design and maintenance of their offices to a company like WeWork.

"We only have 200,000 members," McKelvey, 43, said. "That's ridiculous. We need to have 2 million and then 20 million."

More 'We' Than 'Me'

Bankers and lawyers poured out of skyscrapers and made for the suburbs on a recent Monday night in Manhattan's financial district. But at 110 Wall St., a building controlled entirely by WeWork, the party was just getting started.

The brash, ambitious founders of WeWork, a global network of shared office spaces, want nothing less than to transform the way we work, live and play.

As long and as tall as a cruise ship, the sleek glass structure loomed above rusty, century-old dry docks, serving notice to the industrial neighborhood that the new economy was coming.

The project, known as Dock 72, is the brainchild of WeWork, the fast-growing New York start-up valued at a whopping $20 billion. In just eight years, WeWork has built a network of 212 shared working spaces around the globe. But WeWork’s chief executive and co-founder, Adam Neumann, isn’t content to just lease out communal offices. Mr. Neumann — a lanky, longhaired 38-year-old Israeli — wants nothing less than to radically transform the way we work, live and play.

When Dock 72 is completed this year, if the aggressive timeline holds, it will represent the fullest expression of Mr. Neumann’s expansive vision to date. There will be an enormous co-working space, a luxury spa and large offices, for other companies like IBM and Verizon, that are designed and run by WeWork. There will be a juice bar, a real bar, a gym with a boxing studio, an outdoor basketball court and panoramic vistas of Manhattan. There will be restaurants and maybe even dry cleaning services and a barbershop.

It will be the kind of place you never have to leave until you need to go to sleep — and if Mr. Neumann has his way, you’ll sleep at one of the apartments he is renting nearby.

It’s an all-encompassing sort of ambition, and Mr. Neumann is the brash and idealistic pitchman. Simply by encouraging strangers to share a beer at the office, he argues, WeWork can heal our fractured society.

“How do you change the world?” Mr. Neumann asked in a recent interview. “Bring people together. Where is the easiest big place to bring people together? In the work environment.”

It may sound simplistic, but around the globe, companies are buying whatever it is that Mr. Neumann and his co-founder, Miguel McKelvey, are selling. WeWork has rapidly expanded to 20 countries, assembled a formidable executive team and attracted some 200,000 members. Big companies like JPMorgan Chase and Siemens are signing on as tenants, and revenues are growing fast, expected to top $2.3 billion this year.

That deal was made possible in part by a recent $4.4 billion   investment from   SoftBank, the Japanese technology group led by the enigmatic billionaire Masayoshi Son.

It acquired Meetup, the social network that facilitates in-person gatherings, and   the Flatiron School, a coding academy. Still to come: WeGrow, the company’s   for-profit elementary school, set to open in September. WeWork has even invested in plans to create giant wave pools for inland surfing.

A company ostensibly about co-working now employs yoga instructors, architects, teachers, environmental scientists, software engineers, molecular biologists and social psychologists.

As WeWork expands in all directions, it faces persistent questions about its rich valuation and the durability of its business model. Critics argue that the company does little more than corporate real estate arbitrage — leasing a space, spiffing it up, then subleasing it out to other tenants. The company owns hardly any properties, giving it precious few hard assets. Its growth projections strike many as unattainable, and it has missed expectations before. A number of upstarts loom as potential competitors, seeking to replicate WeWork’s success. And many WeWork tenants are unproven start-ups that could quickly fold.

IWG, a publicly traded co-working company that has more members and more real estate than WeWork, is valued at just $2 billion. Yet Mr. Neumann has convinced investors that WeWork is worth 10 times that figure.

He believes there’s an energy behind the brand, and he’s gotten people to invest at that valuation. He has not tried to explain it in traditional financial terms.”

It’s a state of consciousness, he argues, a generation of interconnected emotionally intelligent entrepreneurs. And Mr. Neumann, with his combination of inspiration and chutzpah, wants to transform not just the way we work and live, but the very world we live in.

It’s an audacious, perhaps delusional plan for a company that made its mark by building communal desks and providing refreshments. And so far, it seems to be working.

Mr. Son, WeWork’s largest investor, is betting that the company will grow exponentially in the years to come, making his multibillion-dollar investment a veritable bargain.

“Make it 10 times bigger than your original plan,” Mr. Son told Forbes late last year. “If you think in that manner, the valuation is cheap. It can be worth a few hundred billion dollars.”

Close Communities

The notion that white-collar workers might actually like their offices is a relatively new one. From the countinghouses of industrial England to the skyscrapers of 1980s Manhattan, offices were mostly uninspiring places designed to maximize space, often with row upon row of unglamorous desks.

Eddy, Troy Edgar, Morgan Wright, Katie FratesNEWSFinancial032801cb.233The White House Announced President Trump's First Major Trade Deal Since Being Elected; Leftist Media As Always Focus More On Non-Substantive News Than What The Trump Administration Has Done; Liberals FromCalifornia Are Pushing Back On The Citizenship Question On 2020 Census; White House Confirmed Veterans Affairs Secretary David Shulkin Will be Resigning and Will be Replaced by President Trump's Personal Physician, Admiral Ronny Jackson; Portions of Atlanta's Government was Shut Down Due to Another Hack Attack that Happened this Past Week; City Officials Still Investigating the Matter and Trying to Assess the Extent of the DamageJohn Layfield, Nicole Pettalides, Gianno Caldwell, Connell McShane

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE-SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The president secured a dramatically improved trade agreement with the Republic of Korea continuing to fulfill one of his key campaign promise to the American people, since the United States Korea Free Trade Agreement, commonly referred to as KORUS, went into effect in 2012, the U.S. trade deficit increased by 70 percent from 6.3 billion to 10.7 billion.

This is a big deal for the American automotive industry, it's a big deal for our parts manufacturers, it's a deal for our pharmaceutical companies, and ultimately, it's a big deal and a major win for American workers and American businesses.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

JOHN LAYFIELD, FBN HOST: A win by President Trump for American companies and American workers. The White House announcing its first trade deal today, unveiling its successfully renegotiated a 6-year-old South Korea- U.S. deal, giving President Trump his first major trade deal since being elected.

And the administration saying its maximum pressure campaign is working. China announcing today in a personal message to President Trump, it met with North Korea's Kim Jong-un and that the dictator is pledging to denuclearize. More on that in a minute.

Also tonight, now an entire county is rebelling against California's liberal sanctuary state -- sanctuary state law. Orange County fighting with the Trump administration vowing to fight back. We have the mayor from the small California town that started the chain reaction.

Plus, you won't believe it, billionaire Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg saying he would never sell your information without consent. This was back in 2009. This as the social media giant is facing criticism for how it handled the personal data of millions of its users today. We'll play you the sound.

Tonight, an all-star guest lineup, former deputy assistant to President George W. Bush, Brad Blakeman, RNC spokesperson, Kayleigh McEnany, and cyber security expert Morgan Wright on more U.S. cities being hacked, global intelligence firm chief executive, R.P. Eddy, and Fox News anchor Shannon Bream on how she helped a dying boy get his wish, all tonight.

Politics and money, we got you covered. I'm in for Liz MacDonald. I'm John Layfield. Risk and Reward starts now.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We've lost over a fairly short period of time, 60,000 factories in the country, closed, shuttered, gone. Six million jobs at least, gone. We have a trade deficit of $504 billion. It's really $375 billion.

Many different ways of looking at it, anyway you look at it, it is the largest deficit of any country in the history of our world. With China we're going to be doing a section 301 trade action. It could be about $60 billion. I'll be signing it right here, right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: The Dow closing the day down just slightly 9 point to 23,848. The NASDAQ also ending lower for a second day as Amazon and Netflix's shares drop. More on that in a moment.

But first, President Trump stepping up for American workers and businesses in his first major trade deal since being elected. The U.S. and South Korea reaching what officials are hailing as a quote, "innovative trade deal," touted as a roadmap for future negotiations.

In return for exemption from Trump's 25 percent tariff on steel imports, South Korea is agreeing to limit its U.S. steel export to roughly 70 percent of its average expert from 2015 to 2017, allow twice as many U.S. made cars 50,000 for manufacturer enter Korea without meeting local safety standards, and extend for 20 years a 25 percent tariff on South Korean pickup trucks exported to the U.S.

The Trump administration also saying its wrapping up a side deal to deter South Korea currency devaluations.

Joining me now is former deputy assistant to President George W. Bush, Brad Blakeman. Brad, welcome to the show. The trade deal to me, it's the first unilateral trade deal that we've done, we've dropped down the TPP, we're looking at negotiating -- renegotiating NAFTA.

A little bit of window dressing. A 25 percent tariff for the next 20 years on South Korea pick-ups coming in. There aren't any South Korea imports coming in, so a little bit of window dressing. And as far as cars going there only 10,000 go there anyway, so but the main part about this was the quota. Reducing that by 30 percent of the level from 2015 to 2017. Is this a good deal?

BRAD BLAKEMAN, FORMER PRESIDENT GEORGE W. BUSH'S DEPUTY ASSISTANT: It's a great deal. It's a heck of a lot better than what we had. And the president is right to get out of this multilateral deals and deal bilaterally with countries.

Look, we have, we are sending $23 billion a year to South Korea, and they're sending back about 2.5 billion, that's not fair trade at all and can't be considered free trade when they have restrictions that are not reciprocal on our end. So it's going to take us a while to ramp up the amount of cars we sell.

But we can start selling auto parts to them tomorrow. This is a very good deal and it's just a start, and other countries should wake up because Donald Trump is going to be knocking on your door very soon.

LAYFIELD: Well, we only sold 10,000 cars last year between G.M. and Ford so it's not going to sell a lot of cars out of this deal, the main deal is that the trade tariff itself reducing to 30 percent below.

BLAKEMAN: Right.

LAYFIELD: How does this not just raise prices, and how would this quota, even though it is a quota not a tariff be different as far as actions that happened in steel prices rising and jobs being cost in our own country right here in the United States like the 2002 Bush tariff did on steel?

BLAKEMAN: Well, what we've got to do is we've got to o look beyond just this steel and look at steel like we do any other product from a national global standpoint.

We are getting screwed. And the status quo is not good enough. And once we start making more deals you'll see that the deals overall will start equalizing themselves. But we have to start standing up for the American worker, and we also have to stand up to unfair trade practices by other countries, friend and foe alike.

LAYFIELD: And the fact that there is 140,000 jobs in steel producing industries and 6.5 million you're not worried about the disparity between the two that this will affect that 6.5 million much greater than we'll add jobs that 140,000?

BLAKEMAN: No, because I think that overall once we get finished with, you know, leveling the playing field, I think we'll have a great deal of good to happen, not only to our workforce but also our economy in general. I think it's about time that we start equalizing the standing that America has. We are a super power, yet we're treated like just another nation. Under Obama that was fine. Under Trump unacceptable.

LAYFIELD: The media today though, Brad, was not interested in America's first trade deal. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Did the president direct John Dowd to talk to the attorneys of Paul Manafort and Michael Flynn without potential pardon?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: A quick question on Stormy Daniels and the lawsuit that was offered overnight.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: If I could ask you about the president's former lawyer, John Dowd, are there any actions that Mr. Dowd took while he was serving the president that President Trump was uncomfortable?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Why has he not spoken to Stormy Daniels, Sarah?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: Is the media missing something here, Brad?

BLAKEMAN: It's a preoccupation. This is -- this is again just a part of the resistance that started the day he was the elected president and it continues. Look, they don't talk about full employment, they don't talk about interest rates, they don't talk about pretty much nonexistence of inflation. Look, if it wasn't for bad news, they wouldn't report any news. And this is -- the American people get it, though.

LAYFIELD: I think you are right.

BLAKEMAN: They really do.

LAYFIELD: And Brad, thank you very much for your time today.

BLAKEMAN: My pleasure.

LAYFIELD: As the North Korea peace talks draw closer, a reminder how unhappy the media is about former Ambassador John Bolton as appointment as our new national security adviser. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This may be the worst thing he has done. He said to them no more stupid wars, now he brings in the godfather of stupid wars, John Bolton.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I think that the risk of a war of a shooting war with Iran, and North Korea are substantially greater than they were this morning. I think it dramatically increases the risk that a lot of Americans and Koreans, perhaps Japanese, end up dead.

JULIETTE KAYYEM, CNN NATIONAL SECURITY ANALYST: John Bolton, he is the hammer and everything is a nail.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Just throwing all the toys in the air, I'm mad, I'm getting rid of everything.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: Despite all this, my next guest said that there is a silver ling with Bolton's pick. Global intelligence firm chief executive, R.P. Eddy, and the author of "Finding Cassandra to Prevent Catastrophes" alongside Richard Clarke, and I think the most -- the best intelligent expert in the world today. So, R.P. thank you for joining us.

All of this talks about Bolton, he has his hand on the trigger. He has said he is for a preemptive strike in Iran and North Korea, but you say there is a silver lining.

R.P. EDDY, CHIEF EXECUTIVE, GLOBAL INTELLIGENCE: There is a silver lining, but John, I don't you to be too optimistic about my view. So, there is a -- there is a -- you know, if you think of a spectrum of political position inside of the Washington, D,C, beltway policy world, John Bolton lives on one extreme, there's no doubt about it. But he is still within that one mainstream dialogue and I think that matters.

And the thing that matters more to me is Donald Trump unfortunately now seems to be throwing away a number of good advisers, and believe me, he can make a lot of decisions on his own, and I don't think that any president on his own can handle the massive complexity of the presidency. Although I see him sort of, steering that direction.

So a guy like John Bolton, though I don't love his policies, in fact, I really dislike some of them, he is a loud guy, he's got a point of view on a lot of things and the president will not be able to throw his opinion away, so at least the president will have a real veteran hand with him.

And this guy, he understands the State Department, he understands the DOD, he understand the international negotiations, he understand the U.N. He doesn't like most of those things but at least he knows how it works, and at least the president won't be able to ignore him, and that matters to me.

I want the president to have as much counsel around him as he can. I'm not speaking about if I love or hate Trump and I didn't since, I just want the president to have good counsel or at least some wise counsel. And though John Bolton's positions are different than mine he will give him counsel.

LAYFIELD: Bolton you say is a loud guy, I think it's fair to say our president could be classified as the same so you have two loud guys in the room. And now, North Korea is at the bargaining table, did this come about because of China stepping up, because of the U.S. And why did they come to the bargaining table.

EDDY: I will always take a pessimistic view on North Korea until I'm proved wrong until we can begin to be optimistic.

LAYFIELD: They've only lied about everything else.

EDDY: You got it. And so, look, I think the Olympics was a really smart thing, it was nice to get everyone kind of, you know, reduce the tensions that's a valuable thing we bought some time, but time actually serves the North Koreans not us, right?

So the next thing North Koreans have to do tactically is they have to prove that one of their ICBM's can deliver a payload to the United States or within that kind of radius. Once they do that, they have every card they need for negotiation.

And as long as they can delay us from doing a preventive attack which Bolton wants, which the president is entertained, which McMaster even entertained, as long as they can prevent that, and it's a great idea to throw a card out there since they want to negotiate to saw things down, they can get to the point where they can be able to show that delivery then they have more to negotiate with. So, it's kind of what I think is going on.

LAYFIELD: Would they really disarm? I mean, is this something--

(CROSSTALK)

EDDY: I would love if they did, but never say never.

LAYFIELD: But what happens if they don't?

EDDY: It depends on your view of this, right. So, it depends very simply. If you think North Korea can be trusted as a rational safe holder of nuclear weapons or not. And historically, everything they have said about nuclear weapons would lead you to that latter position, we really can't trust these guys, they've never said anything about being responsible actors.

Until a few months ago when they came out and said, listen, don't worry we're not maniacs, we're not going to nuke anybody. We'll be responsible nuclear actors. If they can continue that dialogue, if they can get some safe weapon handling procedures and protocols in place, as other countries did, like India, Pakistan, and Israel, then maybe we can say, look, as much as we hate the idea we've learned they're not crazy and we can allow them to have some degree of nuclear weapons.

If we can't get to that point of view we're in a really tough pickle, and then all of a sudden the John Bolton ideas, which currently seem crazy seam less crazy.

LAYFIELD: And what does the Korean peninsula look like if they do disarm, do you see a reunification? Do you see this--

(CROSSTALK)

EDDY: Well, if they do disarm they're not doing it because they don't want to get rid of weapons, they're doing it because they want something massive in return.

And you know, the way I kind of joke about it, if the leaders want their kids to play soccer at Stanford, right, they want to get back into the world, they want their kids to go play football. And they want to get back into the world. So it won't be a matter of, you know, business as usual, they want trade back on, or be at the oil fields that they have offshore which are massive.

They'll be back in the community of nations, they'll have their provision and they want to get going. Now the question then is, can you have a South Korea, North Korea two country so radically different, will they change their system of governance or not, will they stop with some of the chemical weapons issue, the biological weapons issue and the other stuff we care about.

But so long as they're back in the community of nations, you know, then you have a lot of questions out, again, proliferation. These are bad actors on all sorts of scales.

LAYFIELD: This isn't fair. We only have few seconds left, but Russia, are we doing enough to stop Russia actually hacking into the next election?

EDDY: No, we're not. And you know, I know it's contrary to a lot of your guests on here. This president hasn't done enough to stand up against Russia. But I was really heartened to see that he kicked these diplomats out recently. I think that was a good thing joining our NATO our very special allies in Britain. There is a lot more he needs to do against Russia in our state.

Remember, elections are managed at the state level, that means you got every knucklehead in every small state trying to tell me he can prevent a hack from Russia, he can't do it. It is a massive vulnerability and it needs to be fixed.

Simply every machine needs a paper trail, that simple. That's all you got to do. They're still hackable but if you leave your voting booth, and you got a paper certificate that says you voted as you did and you put that in different bucket, now we have a trail and we don't have to worry as much about the hacking. It's still a big problem. Twenty two states were hacked in the last election at least, and if you can see it you can change it as they say in information operations.

LAYFIELD: R.P., I'll put out on Twitter that it was great to have you on and you're like a Santa Claus. You deliver.

EDDY: John, it's always good to see you. Thank you.

LAYFIELD: Great to see you as well. Thank you very much, R.P.

Let's check your money, stocks down a second day on worries about regulation of big tech names. Nicole Pettalides is on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange with the latest. Nicole.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN CORRESPONDENT: John, they did it again. That volatility is here on Wall Street. Back and forth action throughout the day. And the Dow was pretty much 50/50 for winners and losers. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished down 9, so down two days in a row. The S&P 500 down a quarter of 1 percent.

The winners on the Dow, Merck, Wal-Mart, G.E., Travelers and Verizon. Telecom did very well today. Amazon gets beaten down, this after their report that President Trump is looking to change the tax treatment of Amazon, concerns about the mom and pop shops, while all the rest of the retailers got a pop, J.C. Penney and Sears, all of them with up arrows. Tesla is to the downside. This, as federal regulators are looking into that fatal crash. And Moody's was at debt (Ph) its downgrade for Tesla. John?

LAYFIELD: It's so much easier to report when stocks are up. Thank you, Nicole.

Coming up, a heartwarming story for Easter. Fox News Shannon Bream getting the help of the Avengers stars to help make a dying boy's wish come true. Coming up, she is here to talk about how she did it.

Plus, you won't believe it. Billionaire Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg saying he would never sell your information without consent back in 2009. We have the sound.

But first, now at least 12 states are going to sue to block the Trump administration from asking about citizenship on the 2020 census. My next guest think it's ridiculous. RNC spokesperson Kayleigh McEnany joins me next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Let's be realistic about this. Do we think this is about getting an accurate view of the census, and protecting voting rights, or is it to in fact suppress minority voting?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This administration that has consistently tried to suppress voting rights.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Civil rights groups slamming the move saying it could significantly reduce responses from immigrants fearful of deportation.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Adding the question, could scare off undocumented immigrants from participating, potentially throwing off federal funding.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Critics say this is about intimidating immigrants and will result in a population under count, potentially that could lead to lost congressional seats.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: What do you say to critics who argue that ultimately this is a way to target immigrants?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: The media going haywire over a census question. Now at last 12 states are going to sue to block the Trump administration from asking about citizenship on the 2020 census. Opponents of the move say the question will keep even legal immigrants from completing the form which would reduce the population count in Democratic areas of the country.

Joining me now is RNC spokesperson, Kayleigh McEnany. Kayleigh, welcome to the show. Is this question, it's been deemed as if it's a political question. The left says you're trying to suppress immigrant voters, the right says just exactly the opposite.

Is this really something that is being used as a power grab for the vote, the administration or is this simply a question trying to find out who's in our country?

KAYLEIGH MCENANY, SPOKESPERSON, RNC: This is trying to find out who is in our country, and liberals are acting insane here. We're simply trying to find out who is here, who is a citizen, who is not. And guess why we are trying to figure that out, because this census will determine how many representatives each state gets in Congress.

You look back to 2010, the states that gain seats were Florida, Arizona, Texas, states that do have heavy illegal immigrant population. So if these individuals are registering, they appear to be citizens and they get extra representation for that, that cannot happen.

We need to have citizens representing in Congress and not illegal immigrants. Plain and simple.

LAYFIELD: And you don't have to answer the question, that's one thing that's not been pointed out a lot of times. You don't have to answer the question except for how many people are in your household, when it comes to questions protected by the first amendment.

Fox News' Tucker Carlson got into a very heated debate with an illegal immigrant lawyer. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TUCKER CARLSON, FOX NEWS HOST: Do you think that census ought to be allowed to ask people's race?

CESAR VARGAS, ILLEGAL IMMIGRANT LAWYER: Well I think we should have a simple count. That's it.

CARLSON: Yes or no.

VARGAS: And maybe no. I think we shouldn't have immigration status, we shouldn't have about race. We should have say, hey, how many people live in your house, that's it. That's what the Constitution requires. It's all about allocation and representation.

(CROSSTALK)

CARLSON: Well, what about male or female, should ask that, should be allowed or is that unconstitutional too?

VARGAS: Well, I think if a person wants to designate hey, I'm a male, I'm a female, let them -- let them answer that question.

(CROSSTALK)

CARLSON: But why -- but hold on, that wasn't the question. The census asks are you a man or a woman, are you non-Hispanic white, are you African- American, are you American-Indian, and now it's going to ask are you a citizen. Only one of the questions bothers you, not because of the constitutionality of it, but because you think it might dilute the political power of illegal aliens.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: Kayleigh, is asking about citizenship different from asking about race?

MCENANY: Not at all, Tucker was spot on here and he schooled this lawyer quite handedly for a reason because this lawyer is trying to using to pun our Constitution that aren't there, you have a right to ask all of these questions, the government certainly does, these 12 states that are suing, it's a hoax lawsuit, it will not succeed, this Supreme Court will rebuke them much like they did with the travel pause that was struck down by another liberal judge.

LAYFIELD: Well, another conservative commentator, Michelle Malkin says the left wants to use the census as a power grab as I mentioned earlier. Watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MICHELLE MALKIN, LIBERAL COMMENTATOR: Only in America does a country get sued for asking who is in it. It is complete insanity. Only in America do have sworn politicians who have taken an oath of office to uphold the laws and Constitution of this country, out there lambasting the Trump administration for asking a very simple question.

What this is about is about power, more people, more seats, and if you can count illegal aliens as part of that, it's no illegal alien left behind, that's what we're really talking about here.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: Kayleigh, if this indeed a power grab, as Michelle describes, it, what happens in the midterms? The president's party, 35 of 38 times since the Civil War has lost seats in the House, what makes it different this time, or will the history going to repeat itself.

MCENANY: Well, I think we're looking quite good for the midterms. But it's important that we make sure that the people who are voting in the midterms are citizens of the United States, and it's important looking 10 years down the road, 6 to 8 years down the road that the number of seats in Congress are determined by the number of citizens in the states.

Michelle Malkin was spot on. The man in Iowa, the woman in Missouri, and some if these central states that don't have these influxes of illegal immigrant population, they are disenfranchised every time a seat is added to California because they are over counting the number of people that reside in that state.

LAYFIELD: Kayleigh, thank you very much. Now an entire county is rebelling against California's liberal sanctuary state law. Orange County deciding what the Trump administration vowing to fight back. Next, the mayor of the small California town that started the chain reaction, Los Alamitos mayor with me now is Troy Edgar.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHAWN NELSON, SUPERVISOR, ORANGE COUNTY, CALIFORNIA: California is trying to poke president in the eye and stir up trouble, and really involve our people by ordering them not to do the job of the federal government, but to not even cooperate with the function of federal law enforcement. And it's not good for our society, and we're tired of being the pawns.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: Orange County taking a stand defying California's new sanctuary law, voting to join a federal lawsuit against the new state law aimed at telling local officials not to work with federal officials to arrest the felons.

President Trump appalling the move tweeting, quote, "My administration stands in solidarity with the brave citizens in Orange County defending their right against California's illegal and unconstitutional sanctuary policies. California sanctuary laws release known dangerous criminals in the community across the states. All citizens have the right to be protected by federal law and strong borders."

This anti-sanctuary vote coming one week after the city of Los Alamitos did the same. With me now is Troy Edgar, the mayor of Los Alamitos. Mayor, it seems like something big has started. I guess, my question is, who's going to get arrested? Is the sheriff going to get arrested? Is the attorney general is going -- because you have a violation here of state law, but you also have a violation of federal law, you can't do both in this situation.

TROY EDGAR, MAYOR, LOST ALAMITOS, CALIFORNIA: Right.

LAYFIELD: And so what's the answer.

(CROSSTALK)

EDGAR: Well, at this point -- yes, at this point I would hope no one is going to get arrested at least from the side of sheriff. I think our sheriff in Orange County, Sheriff Hutchens says did a brave move, we watch Sheriff Mims up in Fresno County, you know, these are people that are really trying to figure out a constructive way to do it, just like us on city council and county supervisors are trying to get through either get in or answer a lawsuit going at the U.S. government.

LAYFIELD: Orange County sheriff, we mentioned, taking a stand publicly posting inmate release states to help federal immigration agents, much to the dislike of the state's attorney general. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDRA HUTCHENS, SHERIFF-CORONER, ORANGE COUNTY, CALIFORNIA: What I'm doing is entirely within the confines of the law, and I'm doing what I think is important for my constituents. It's a public safety issue to me, it's not about immigration at all.

CARLSON: Right.

HUTCHENS: It's about individuals who have committed violent crimes, and I don't think I could sleep at night knowing that I let somebody go, and they go out and commit another crime.

If he is going to arrest me, then he better have some good changes, because I'm going to get an attorney and I'll fight it. But I would be surprised if Mr. Becerra decides to make a move like that and arrest a sitting sheriff for following just because he doesn't like what I'm doing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: Mayor, you mentioned that you didn't think that anybody would be arrested. I think you're right, but this is a crazy position for the sheriff to be in, for the A.G. to be in, for Jeff Sessions to be in. What happens next?

Did we lose the sheriff? We lost the sheriff. So, Troy Edgar was the mayor of Los Alamitos. We're going to go to break, but when we come back, you won't believe it.

Billionaire Facebook co-founder Mark Zuckerberg saying he would never sell your information without consent back in 2009. We have the sound.

LAYFIELD: Breaking news. White House officials confirming that Veteran Affairs Secretary David Shulkin to resign. Officials saying President Trump will nominate his personal physician Ronny Jackson to succeed him.

Donald J. Trump, the president, tweeting, and I quote, "I am pleased to announce that I intend to nominate highly respected Admiral Ronny Jackson, M.D. ad the new veteran -- secretary of Veterans Affairs. In the interim, honorable Robert Wilkie of DOD, Department of Defense will serve as acting secretary. I am thankful for Dr. David Shulkin's service to our country and to our great veterans."

New video uncovered. We're going to spun to that in a minute, Gianno. But I want to get first to this -- first, Gianno, I want to -- OK, sorry. Sorry about that. We got breaking news, we got a live TV, we just lost the mayor of an entire city just a second ago on live television, so anything can happen.

(CROSSTALK)

GIANNO CALDWELL, POLITICAL ANALYST, FOX NEWS: Wait a minute, he is still alive, right?

LAYFIELD: We don't know that, he could have got arrested by either the attorney general or Jeff Sessions.

CALDWELL: My God. No, no, I hope not, I hope not, so he still alive.

LAYFIELD: So Gianno Caldwell and Katie Frates, your initial thoughts on this, we had an expletive said by one of our cameraman when they heard this that they couldn't believe it.

CALDWELL: Yes.

LAYFIELD: I think a little bit of exasperation, I think you have the same feeling. What do you think President Trump's personal position taking over?

CALDWELL: Well, honestly, I mean, there's a four -- a few different things that come to mind when I hear a story like this. One, we continue to see the moving chairs on White House in terms of administration that people continue to go and come. And I think for a lot of people they want to see a little bit more stability.

In terms of the current secretary who just resigned, I know he had solid support among veterans groups. To some this isn't as much as a surprise. I think there was some bumping of the heads within the administration.

But certainly, when it comes to Trump's personal doctor, how does one feel about him nominating that person when we know President Trump likes to get people that he is very familiar with on a personal note and nominate them to things.

So that could be pretty good. We've got to find out more about this guy. Because at this time I don't know much about him or anything about him or anything at all, besides the fact that he is Trump's personal physician, do you?

LAYFIELD: No, I don't, nothing except for the fact that President Trump continues to appear from the outside to have disarray in his office.

To Katie Frates who actually came on here to talk about Facebook. So, Katie, I hate to surprise you with this news, but it's breaking to us as well. Is this a sign, as Gianno mentioned and I alluded too, that this is disarray in Trump White House. You had hard turnover in the Trump White House by factor of two--

KATIE FRATES, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, THE DAILY CALLER NEWS FOUNDATION: Right.

LAYFIELD: -- than any administration in history, is this more of the same? And is it disarray?

FRATES: This is actually the first time I have heard breaking news like this and been relieved by it. I'm really hoping that the exit of Secretary Shulkin is the last in line of V.A. secretaries to have let down the men and women of this country who protect it and who need our help once they come home.

The V.A. continues to have story after story that lets our veterans down of horrific situation. And I'm hoping while I agree with Gianno, we absolutely need to know more about his nominee, that this can hopefully be a new era for the protection of our veterans when they come home.

LAYFIELD: Well, this person may be incredibly qualified, and I hope they are, and I agree with you about the Veterans Administration. I've been to visit Iraq and Afghanistan eight different times, but a lot of Christmases over there with these incredible heroes. I have a soft spot for these guys especially the care that these veterans have once they return.

But is this more a sign of President Trump just bringing in his inner circle to the White House, and is it more of a sign of disarray. Forget the fact that this person needs to be replaced. Is this a sign of disarray and chaos in White House?

FRATES: I'm not entirely sure. I mean, we've been hearing disarray and chaos in White House the entire time President Trump has been our president. We've heard that even before he was our president. So I'm not thinking much of this, specifically because Secretary Shulkin was not doing his job.

So I think we need to take back -- a step back and look and see is this person resigning, and that's a good thing, is that separate from the chaos we may see is there. And I think it is. I think it's a good thing that he is resigning.

LAYFIELD: Gianno, Rex Tillerson was fired by Twitter. Some would think a person of that distinguished of a career would have deserved a little better than that.

CALDWELL: Priebus is also went let go and left in an airport field, right?

LAYFIELD: That is correct.

CALDWELL: Yes.

LAYFIELD: And is this the Trump administration their style of leadership is this going to work?

CALDWELL: Well, I got to push back a little bit because I think there has been disarray and chaos within the White House, certainly it looks that way from the outside looking in and this isn't something that is traditional of any presidency, I think President Trump has called himself modern day presidential.

So with that being the case, I'm hoping that this isn't a revolving door of imagery that we're going to see throughout this White House. But certainly when it comes to case by case, by Tillerson, who some like some didn't, there's other people who have left the White House, there are some like and some didn't.

When it comes to the veterans this is a very serious issue, and I know there was a group yesterday that said that there was going to be an imminent departure, which there was. And I know Katie wants to jump in there, so go ahead.

LAYFIELD: Go ahead, Katie.

FRATES: So actually if you could repeat that I just had something in my ear so I actually can't hear you.

LAYFIELD: Well, Katie, let me ask you, let me ask you a different question about inclusiveness. The thing against Trump administration is the fact that you bringing in personal friends, you brought in a lot of family.

FRATES: Right.

LAYFIELD: And most of the people that are there, you look at Mr. Bolton. You look at Rex Tillerson. You look at Mr. Ross, Secretary Ross. We have an average age of about 80 years old it seems like in this White House. Is this White House really in touch?

FRATES: Well, absolutely it's concerning to me to see a president who may be surrounding himself and seems like time and time again he is surrounding himself by people who are friends first as opposed to necessarily qualified first, so that's absolutely something that is a concern.

But I also think we need to be objective in looking at again this, the potential new V.A. secretary his qualification, his relationship with the president aside. But I am I do completely agree with the idea that it seems a little odd when everyone happens to be a close friend.

LAYFIELD: Yes, the pattern it seems to be a very suspect, Gianno, I would think.

CALDWELL: Well, President Trump just called me -- hello, president, I'm a close friend too, so I think he nominated me.

LAYFIELD: You're going to the White House. Actually -- yes.

(CROSSTALK)

CALDWELL: I'm on my way. I'm on my way.

LAYFIELD: Actually, Gianno, you are not going anywhere because we also going to talk about Facebook. So that's exactly -- we're going to keep moving guys. You guys get double duty.

(CROSSTALK)

CALDWELL: I got new duty.

LAYFIELD: That's right. You get breaking news and--

CALDWELL: So I got breaking news.

LAYFIELD: -- you get to talk about what you--

(CROSSTALK)

CALDWELL: I just heard the news the new chief of staff of the White House.

LAYFIELD: I think you would be a great pick?

CALDWELL: Hello, mom, I made it.

LAYFIELD: You said your mother disown you for--

(CROSSTALK)

CALDWELL: I know I'm a republican but she is goin to love me for being the new chief of staff.

LAYFIELD: She -- invite her to the White House your mom will love you forever.

CALDWELL: There you go.

LAYFIELD: I assure you. First, another hack attack on the U.S. city shutting down substantial forces of Atlanta's government. Cyber expert Morgan Wright thinks something bigger is coming. He'll explain after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I have directed the search of security various subject matter experts to work closely with the city's task force to get mission critical systems back on-line as prudently and expeditiously as possible.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: This is much bigger than Ransomware attack. This really is an attack on our government, which means it's an attack on all of us.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LAYFIELD: Another hack attack on U.S. city. With Gianno and Katie, I'm not sure if they are coming back that we have breaking news. So we're coverings whatever is in front of us. So I got to throw that damn teleprompter for a minute. I love it.

Shutting down substantial portions of Atlanta's government of the past week, things still aren't quite back to normal as that city and its officials try to piece together the extent of the damage. Government workers beginning to turn on their computers for the first time since the attack effectively held their systems hostage today.

I'm joined now with cybersecurity expert, Morgan Wright, here to react to the growing trend. Is -- Morgan, thank you very much for joining us. I appreciate this. We got a little disarray because of breaking news, which is actually a lot of fun to cover a lot of television.

MORGAN WRIGHT, CYBERSECURITY EXPERT: Right.

LAYFIELD: But is this becoming a national security issue.

WRIGHT: It was a couple years ago, people just tend to realize. Look, John, in 2015, the global damage from Ransonware was $350 million. In 2017, it was $5 billion and it's growing. This is a weaponize form of malicious software and it's design to do one thing on stuff like this. They go after health care, they go after and governments, why, because they have to pay because these are mission-critical services and this stuff is mutating.

Colorado Department of Transportation off line, can't pay their employees. I mean, this is significant impact, so, yes, I expect -- I expect it to increase over the next three to four years.

LAYFIELD: Morgan, how does the Ransom actually take place? So you have something held hostage, I understand Ransonware and entire principle, so how do they actually pay whoever this is as perpetrating these crimes?

WRIGHT: Crypto currency bitcoin is the crypto currency of choice. I mean, these folks have 800 numbers and customer service numbers that would make U.S. corporations, you know, jealous. These guys are good about getting the money out of you. What they do is that, you have to set up an account, you fund that account with bitcoin because it's virtually untraceable.

And then, for example, in Atlanta I think they want about 50, or $51,000, you know, and that for a city to do this calculation, understand it's going to cost more than that to get our data back. So, unfortunately, some of these cities and counties, Charlotte-Mecklenburg the recent one to have paid the ransom.

LAYFIELD: Where are these attacks coming from? Is this a sovereign state of these are just hackers around the world that are doing these to destruct commerce and hopefully make, for them, make a little money off of it.

WRIGHT: They've actually been both. The Wannacry, the Ransomware attack that was North Korea. They actually used some NSA tools the EternalBlue to exploit a vulnerability in Windows in the server in some of these case. These are organize crime groups. A Ransonware manager in Romania or Russia could 150to $200,000 a year and that's significant over there and the people on this team.

So, it is all over the place, it is state sponsored in some areas, Russia has sponsored this as attacks on Ukraine, but at the same time criminal enterprises are the ones they're after the money, not so much Russia.

LAYFIELD: And there's more ways that Kim Jong-un is actually financing part of what he is doing--

WRIGHT: Yes.

LAYFIELD: -- with these sanctions that are crippling because they have a huge cadre of hackers from North Korea that are operating, I believe, out China, correct?

WRIGHT: Yes, absolutely. In fact, not only China but in places like Thailand, you know, other places outside that. In fact, North Korea attacked a lot of the bitcoin and crypto currency changes -- exchanges in South Korea to do exactly that to start getting some hard currency. Stuff that they've been prohibited from by a lot of these export restrictions.

LAYFIELD: Over the weekend, a different hack attack disrupting Baltimore's 911 dispatch system for 17 hours. The question, I guess, these people, is this all just about ransom or is this simply a foreign country? Is it tied in to the Russian meddling and Yevgeny Prigozhin and what he had with his IRA that was trolling allegedly the elections?

WRIGHT: Right. You know, this is interesting too, because as we start moving more towards a network centric environment, it used to be 911 centers were based on copper wire the old stuff, but now they are network base so you can be anywhere.

So the ability to attack this are increasing. We've got a brand new big public network coming onboard called FirstNet, that's also going to be (Inaudible), so these threats are going to increase.

LAYFIELD: I only got a couple seconds left, so what's the best way to prevent this.

WRIGHT: Back up, back up, back up, don't click on suspicious links, and whatever you do if you see something happening call for help right away.

LAYFIELD: Morgan, that's great stuff. Thank you very much.

WRIGHT: You bet, John.

LAYFIELD: Developing news on Shulkin's ouster, our own Connell McShane after this.

LAYFIELD: Breaking news. White House officials confirming that Veterans Affairs Secretary David Shulkin will resign. Officials saying President Trump will nominate his personal physician Admiral Ronny Jackson to succeed him.

With more on this is Connell McShane. Connell, can you give us some details on this, please, and explain what's going on in the White House?

CONNELL MCSHANE, CORRESPONDENT, FOX BUSINESS: No. Boy, how much time do we have?

LAYFIELD: That's a lot of question, Connell.

(CROSSTALK)

MCSHANE: I'm here on the street of Washington covering a completely different story on the news that's break to my right a few blocks down to Pennsylvania Avenue. But you know, I don't think it's a surprise to anybody that David Shulkin is being forced out of this position. That have been a telegraph move from this president that Mr. Shulkin had come under fire for some of the expenses that have been under his, you know, direction when he was the Veterans Affairs secretary particularly this trip to Europe in which his wife went to Europe.

So, there was, this was a long time coming. But the fact that the president picked his personal physician to take his place that took some people off- guard a little bit. Admiral Jackson has been in the navy for a long time and he's also been the personal physician to the last three presidents.

But this is a move the president has been looking to make for some time which is a matter of who. The choice is interesting though, I think that surprise a lot of people.

LAYFIELD: Well, Connell, you're in D.C., you're a brilliant reporter. This has take you by surprise we have a president who surround himself by his own family and personal friends. And it certainly looks like from the outside in from a 30,000 foot level that this is a sign of disarray and chaos despite the fact that this move itself was a very telegraphed move. But taking his personal physician, does that surprise you?

MCSHANE: Yes, a little bit. I mean, I think the White House has been arguing all along when you bring up that narrative that you just mentioned that this is somehow chaotic situation, that the president is just in year two as he moves in trying to surround himself with people he's comfortable with and trying to build an administration where he is comfortable dealing with the people who advise him.

I would point to you that the John Bolton appointment last week as an example of that. So that's how the White House pushes back on that. But, you know, there is no arguing with the fact that there's been more turnover in this White House in the first year of Trump than there are in normal White House. So that's just a fact.

LAYFIELD: Yes. Two extras turnover of any previous administration. I think Ronald Reagan had the previous record which is pretty good company to be in.

MCSHANE: Yes.

LAYFIELD: But certainly the two ex is something that has raised some alarm. What is the feel in D.C., I mean, you got Congress with approval rating lower than people that believe in big foot for very good reason. What is the feel, I'm not sure who is it that believe in these guys up there in Congress, I guess it's their friends and family.

But what is the feeling in D.C. about this administration as far as the continual shake-up? It certainly appears from the outside looking in.

MCSHANE: Well, they are in recess now for this weekend.

(CROSSTALK)

LAYFIELD: Of course they are.

MCSHANE: Or either back on their own districts or they are on an overseas trip or what have you. But I mean, I don't know that today changes anything in terms of what people were already thinking.

If you are against the president you are going to view the changes that come at high-level as chaotic. If you're somebody who supports the president you are going to say that he just needs to make the type of changes, again, as I said earlier, that he could surround himself with people who are comfortable with.

So, it's completely depends on which side of the aisle that you come down on and what's your view is going to be on something like that. But again, as I've said before and I've been talking to people that are close to or even in the White House, they maintain that -- they push back hard on that chaotic narrative that people have been putting out there and saying, again, the president is just looking to find people that he's comfortable with.

LAYFIELD: Sure.

MCSHANE: And who would you be comfortable with, I guess someone that you work with directly as personal physician. He obviously likes the guys as we saw when he came out, Ronny Jackson, to give the personal -- personal health report for the president there some time ago at the White House.

LAYFIELD: Connell, we only -- we have less than a minute but I want to ask you this about the midterm election.

MCSHANE: OK.

LAYFIELD: The trend is against the president's party 35 of 38 times since the Civil War that the president's party has lost seats. Since 1913 the Senate -- 19 of 26 the president's party has loss seats.

Anti-incumbent sentiment is ravage around the world. Does this party get wiped out in the midterms as history change?

MCSHANE: Well, you could see the president is kind of bracing himself for something wipe out, maybe not the big blue wave that people are looking for that he's been trying to fire up the base to some recent appearance he says he's made of. He keeps talking about the fact that you see this all the time that people get complacent and he's calling on his party to not get complacent. But right now you have the seat advantage as least in the House--

(CROSSTALK)

LAYFIELD: Connell, I don't mean to cut you off, we got to run. We got a hard break coming up and your holiday (Ph) is live on TV.

Charles Payne is now here with Making Money. My man, Charles, take it away.

SARAH HUCKABEE-SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: The president secured a dramatically improved trade agreement with the Republic of Korea continuing to fulfill one of his key campaign promise to the American people, since the United States Korea Free Trade Agreement, commonly referred to as KORUS, went into effect in 2012, the U.S. trade deficit increased by 70 percent from 6.3 billion to 10.7 billion.
