urn:contentItem:6011-JMP1-DYTY-C07N-00000-00THE WORLD'S SHARES2020-05-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:36:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 22,23,24,25,26,27THE WORLD'S SHARES

The 15 international stocks every investor should own. Megan Boxall and the companies team report The steady lifting of lockdown measures has brought a breath of normality back to life in Britain. Busy roads, bustling parks and blooming garden centres are almost reflective of a normal May weekend.

But although we seem to have emerged from the post-apocalyptic mood of lockdown, there is certainly a sense that life is never going back to the old normal. Trends that were starting to shape the way we live precoronavirus have been exposed, and in some cases accelerated by the pandemic.

To capitalise on these trends, investors should look beyond these shores. We have picked 15 international stocks with the ability to bounce back quickly and the capacity to thrive in a post-coronavirus world.

TECHNOLOGY AT THE HEART OF ALL WE DO Satya Nadella, chief executive of software giant Microsoft (US:MSFT), says his company has seen "two years' worth of digital transformation in two months". That's hardly surprising given the sudden increase in remote working and growing demand for cloud infrastructure courtesy of coronavirus.

But the demand for work-from-home software will not keep rising indefinitely - we're not all going to stay away from our offices for good - nor will online socialising and entertainment permanently replace their physical equivalents. That said, the digital transformation that sparked 15 per cent growth in revenues at Microsoft in the first quarter of 2020 is unlikely to entirely reverse. Coronavirus has heightened individual and corporate awareness of the need for strong connectivity, including software and telecoms infrastructure.

It has also brought a new angle to the debate around use of data - government sponsored tracking systems have popped up in many countries in the past few months as authorities scramble to get a full picture of the scale of the coronavirus pandemic. The protection of people's health gives personal data collection a far more acceptable purpose than targeted marketing campaigns. Regulators who have interrogated big tech executives with increasing determination for the past five years might be willing to take a softer stance in the future.

There are, understandably, doubters. "I'm glad that they're willing to help," Republican senator Josh Hawley said of Alphabet's (US:GOOGL) efforts to develop screening mechanisms for Covid-19. "I hope that they're actually helping and not using this as an opportunity to drum up business."

But the future of technology is not just about products and services that are already in place, or what Alex Newman described in his recent feature as "an unending era of ever-sharper iPhone cameras". Innovative solutions to some of the world's most pressing problems - resource competition, climate change, inequality - are increasingly being built by some of the world's biggest technology companies.

There is no better example of this than Alphabet whose 'other bets' division is developing many new technologies in the fields of artificial intelligence, driverless vehicles and green energy. Alphabet's growing Software giants for work and play: Microsoft, Adobe Aside from their exposure to one of the biggest trends in a post-coronavirus world, US tech giants are, mostly, exceptionally high-quality businesses. They have taken very good care of their cash and are going to get through the crisis without any external financial aid, even though they are dishing out millions to help fight the illness. The comparison with cumbersome businesses asking governments for bailouts is stark. The software giants, in particular, have very impressive revenue predictability. Microsoft is increasingly generating revenue from subscriptions, which are reliable and come with very high margins. Adobe (US:ADBE) pioneered the industry's shift from lumpy licensing revenues to subscriptions in 2013. Its proportion of recurring revenue has climbed steadily since then and hit 90 per cent of total sales in 2019.

Maintaining subscriptions requires very little ongoing expenditure, which means the bulk of the revenue at both Microsoft and Adobe comes with gross margins of almost 100 per cent. This feeds back into an exceptionally high return on capital employed and a free cash flow conversion that has averaged more than 100 per cent at both companies for the past five years. We think Adobe and Microsoft should sit near the top of most investors' international wish lists. LA portfolio of early-stage companies has recently drawn comparisons with Warren Buffett's investment giant Berkshire Hathaway, which booked its place in investment history books when it began reinvesting the profits of its insurance business back into other companies. The 'Sage of Omaha' himself expressed his regret back in 2017 that he hadn't cottoned on to Alphabet's growth story sooner. But the era of 'big tech' is far from over - arguably its dominance will only increase as the Covid-19 crisis accelerates key trends and paves the way for longer lasting behavioural changes.

The king of data: Alphabet Alphabet's biggest revenue generator is advertising within search engine Google, the go-to place for online queries. The company's dominance in the advertising market has helped its parent company generate extraordinary levels of cash from its operations. At the end of March 2020, Alphabet was sitting on over $100bn of net cash.

But the ad model is not the future of Alphabet, whose diverse activities offer multiple growth levers. YouTube is pushing into e-sports live-streaming and increasingly generates turnover from subscriptions. These sales form part of Alphabet's 'other' segment, which, together with increased purchases from the Google Play mobile app store, saw revenue jump by more than a fifth to $4.4bn in the first three months of the year.

As the 'internet of things' moves closer to reality, cloud computing will become increasingly important. Alphabet may trail market leaders Amazon and Microsoft with only an 8 per cent share, but its cloud business is growing fast. Google also has what none of its peers have: an unrivalled ability to understand and analyse data. In the future, companies won't just want to host their data in the cloud, they will want to be able to analyse it too and Google's systems should come into their own. NK A NEW ERA IN CONSUMERISM It would be unfair to say that digital shopping is a trend that has been sparked by coronavirus. Amazon (US:AMZN) (see boxout and also our World's Hottest Shares feature on page 32) upended the book retail industry in the early 2000s and has been applying the same ruthless innovation to every sector it has targeted to enter since.

But perhaps the digital habits have filtered through to more sectors and even populations owing to the pandemic and subsequent lockdown. In April, headline US retail sales - a measure of sales in stores and restaurants - plunged 16.4 per cent, according to data from the commerce department. That same month, non-store sales rose by more than a fifth. With these trends unlikely to die down after the pandemic has passed, an increasingly digital consumer world is looking likely.

That would help explain why PayPal's (US:PYPL) share price recently hit an all-time high, even though most of its key markets are entering a recession. Investors are clearly more focused on the fact that a greater proportion of global expenditure will be happening digitally in the coming years than the concern that job losses and recession could stunt overall spending.

Regardless of the immediate economic challenges, a digital strategy and e-commerce arm are crucial to longterm success for retailers and personal goods companies. Keeping one eye on the future is also important for the next link in the chain - the property companies that provide for the retail industry. On one hand, commercial landlords who rent to retailers are sharing in the pain felt by shuttered shops, but on the other, demand for industrial premises that can serve online demand is soaring. Stag Industrials (US:STAG) provides clear evidence of that trend. The group's rent collection has proved resilient since the Covid-19 pandemic took hold, as it collected 99 per cent of March base rental billings and 90 per cent of April base rental billing. Perhaps that is not surprising - the company's number one tenant is Amazon, which is currently servicing more deliveries than it has ever done before.

A volumes game: Visa Visa's (US:V) main activity is to provide banks and other financial institutions with the technology and branding for their payment products - a highly profitable volume game. In recent years, the group's free cash flow margin - that is the proportion of sales being converted into cash - has exceeded 50 per cent.

Consequently, market expectations remain high. Although falling consumer activity means earnings are expected to decline 8 per cent to $5.03 per share this year, analysts predict that profits will soon swing back to regain their momentum of double-digit annual growth. Whether that collective view reflects an overoptimistic assessment of spending and travel, it's worth noting that the company has beaten consensus earnings forecasts in all but two quarters over the past five years.

It also seems likely that Covid-19 will accelerate two major secular trends in Visa's favour, as virus-averse consumers shun physical currency and e-commerce expands its boundless reach into what RBC analysts term "non-traditional" purchase categories, such as food and drugs. In the longer term, it's harder to forecast the trajectory of payments solutions and what competition Visa could face. But solid organic growth, a pre-eminent brand and strong margins mean the company is superbly positioned to adapt to technological change. AN A profitable property play: Stag Industrials Stag Industrials seeks to acquire under-let or vacant industrial properties and increase the rental income. It has a good track record of executing on that strategy, for instance during the first quarter of this year it sold three buildings for a total $102m, resulting in a gain of $47m on the initial aggregate purchase price.

Stag benefits from a diversified tenant base, with no single occupier accounting for more than 2 per cent of annual rental income. The group's balance sheet is also in relatively robust health - it had a debt-to-equity ratio of 34.2 per cent and available cash of $325m at the end of March. In April, the group also refinanced $300m of unsecured debt previously scheduled to mature within the next year.

Annual uplifts and rent reviews boosted same-store cash net operating income by 2.5 per cent during the first quarter to $73.4m. However, management is guiding towards same-store net operating income growth of between 0 and 1 per cent for 2020, based on credit loss guidance of 1.25 percentage points, a tenant retention range of between 60 and 70 per cent and around a 0.7 percentage point impact for a top-10 tenant move-out. EP The 'everything' investment: AmazonAmazon shares defy the normal rules of fundamental analysis. But being priced for both growth and perfection (62 times consensus earnings forecasts) has failed to stop a near-six-fold appreciation over the past five years. In part, this has been due to an unwavering allocation to fast-growing US-based market winners, of which Amazon is an exemplar. It is also recognition of a long-sighted, often creative and sometimes brutal drive to dominate every market it touches.

First-quarter results were a prime example. Predictably, headlines focused on revenues that smashed analyst forecasts, and earnings that were hampered by Covid-19-related costs. The bigger story was Jeff Bezos' plan to invest all of this quarter's operating profits to build a pandemic-proof supply chain, and position Amazon as a leader in at-home testing.

That foresight and imagination, as well as Amazon's sheer corporate power, explain why the investment case rarely focuses on employees' working conditions, or a monopolistic vein which could one day attract political heat. Moreover, the shares represent less an exceptionally well-run conglomerate, than the spirit animal of disruption in a seemingly-unlimited range of sectors. It's difficult to put a price on that (see page 32 for more on Amazon). AN Fitness goals: Garmin Garmin's fitness division has made a strong start to the year. Revenues here rose by 24 per cent during the first three months of 2020 to $224m. But fitness isn't the group's only focus area. It also houses aviation, marine, outdoor, and automobile divisions - selling specialist tracking devices such as autopilot systems, weather radars and, for the piscatorial among us, 'fishfinders'. This diversification should help protect the company in downturns.

That said, management has withdrawn guidance, citing "rapid and unpredictable economic changes". But it entered the crisis in a robust position. Net sales rose by 12 per cent last year to $3.8bn, while operating profits climbed by more than a fifth to $945m. The group also boasted a strong balance sheet, with zero debt and $2.6bn in cash - a financial position it reiterated in late April, and which should be sufficient to "weather any long-term impact" of Covid-19 in JP Morgan's view. That cash also underpins Garmin's sizeable dividend, which rose from $2.12 per share to $2.28 in 2019. HC Look beyond coronavirus: AdidasGerman sportswear giant Adidas (GER:ADS) has all the makings of a company well placed to weather the Covid-19 storm - a solid balance sheet, big brand and a leading position in a market that is set to benefit from current trends. But by the end of its first quarter, the coronavirus pandemic had forced the company's sales down by almost a fifth, with 70 per cent of its stores around the world closed.

Still, that doesn't mean its long-term outlook has been dampened. Adidas management is rigorously preparing the company for the future. Flagship stores and a major e-commerce operation are replacing smaller highstreet retail sites, while online sales have risen from 3 per cent of sales in 2014 to 11 per cent last year.

The e-commerce channel has also proved beneficial to the company's cash flow statement as its own online sales are converted immediately into cash, whereas online sales through wholesale partners take much longer to appear on the company's books. Management can also manage its inventory better if it has full control of its sales channels, providing further stability to the balance sheet, which included net cash of (EURO)873m at the start of 2020. AJ Quick off the Merck New-York-listed Merck (US:MRK) is a leader in immuno-oncology - a field of medicine that has changed the way we treat cancer by stimulating patient's immune systems so they can fight tumour cells.

Merck's Keytruda immunotherapy only hit the market in 2015, but has already been approved across 14 different types of cancers and in the first quarter of 2020 reported 45 per cent revenue growth to $3.3bn - contributing almost a third of Merck's total pharmaceutical sales ($10.7bn). But Merck is far from a one-drug wonder. Its revenues are diversified across various other products, including the Gardasil HPV vaccine and the Januvia type-two diabetes treatment.

True, like many other companies, Merck is enduring coronavirus-led disruption. Distancing measures are knocking demand for doctor-administered medicines, and the group has lowered its full-year guidance. But, while the future might be uncertain, the past offers a solid foundation for growth.

Over the three years to last December, revenues and pre-tax profits rose at a compound annual growth rate of 6 per cent and 35 per cent respectively.

Meanwhile, Merck has also made generous returns to shareholders, paying out $10.5bn in 2019 alone in the form of dividends and buybacks. HC HEALTH IN SHARPER FOCUS The fitness technology industry was worth $26bn in 2018. And, according to the Global Wellness Institute, it is set to enjoy an average annual growth rate of 8.6 per cent over the next few years - reaching $39.8bn in 2023.

Market projections should be treated with additional caution now that we're in the middle of a pandemic. But there's also an argument that lockdown measures may have catalysed an existing trend - driving even more of us towards digital exercise products while we cannot go to the gym. Any such acceleration would be good news for Garmin (US:GRMN), for which fitness constitutes more than 25 per cent of revenues.

The same trends have driven demand at fitness equipment retailers and boosted the 'athleisure' market, which is now expected to hit a $257bn valuation by 2026, from $155bn last year. Meanwhile, gym companies are desperate to open - aside from the revenue they are missing out on when in lockdown, there is a real danger than alternative solutions might dissuade people from continuing their expensive memberships.

It's not just fitness goals we have in mind when we talk about post-coronavirus health priorities. The pandemic has exposed frailties in global health systems that need to be addressed - better hygiene and personal care among them.

For now, the pharmaceutical industry is dominated by discussion about testing and vaccines for Covid-19, but even when the current pandemic dies down, focus on infectious diseases is likely to remain. Indeed, a strategy for dealing with illnesses caused by both viruses and bacteria has been among the top priorities for the World Health Organisation for many years. Regulation can help stimulate investment in areas of unmet need.

The need for medical efficiency - which includes keeping patients out of hospital - has also been accelerated by the pandemic. For too long the pharmaceutical industry has thrived on a model of making big margins from 'maintenance medicines' - those that treat nonlife-threatening diseases - and has trailed the innovation coming out of universities and research centres. Greater focus on commercialising the world's best new science, including genetic medicine and digital health, is crucial if we are going to avoid future pandemics.

HOW WE EAT Life under lockdown has transformed the way we eat. The coronavirus pandemic has been terrible for restaurants and bars. But it has also sparked a surge in supermarket shopping, driving people to cook (or microwave) at home. And Swiss-listed Nestlé (CH:NESN) has ridden the crest of that wave. The food and drinks behemoth beat analysts' expectations for the first three months of 2020, unveiling a 4.3 per cent uptick in organic revenues to CHF20.8bn (£17.7bn), driven by demand for frozen food and baking products.

Stockpiling long-life goods during lockdown is a useful string to the bow of those who argue that the recent rise in healthy eating is a short-term fad, driven by wealthy westerners in times of prosperity. It's true that price might become more problematic if we are entering a long period of economic turbulence. But the cost and availability of healthy food has come down dramatically in the past few years. That is especially true of vegetarian and vegan products. Demand for meat-free food increased by almost 1,000 per cent in 2017 and has continued to rise sharply as food producers help make vegetarian options more readily available. Supermarkets now stock many meat alternatives at reasonable prices and vegetarians in restaurants have more options than mushroom risotto and goats cheese tart. Even McDonald's (US:MCD) now sells vegan burgers.

It isn't just the demand side of the food industry where sentiment is starting to shift. Meat supply is coming under scrutiny as environmentalists call into question the efficiency of production - it reportedly takes 10 kilograms (kg) of vegetables to grow every one kg of cow. And the push towards greener lifestyles is certainly not expected to disappear postcoronavirus. Indeed, environmental initiatives are being touted as a key area of investment to help bring us out of the economic hole created by the pandemic and subsequent lockdown - a topic we discussed at length in the introduction to our new series of features 'A New Future'.

GOING GREENER Consumer demand for green initiatives - including veganism, slower fashion and 'staycations' - is just one part of the clean environment story. Policy is also important. National decarbonisation targets encourage governments to offer subsidies for clean energy development and usage. The third (and perhaps most crucial) link in the chain is a greater capacity to supply green energy. In the past few years as the cost of building windfarms has come down, efficiency has increased and demand has gone up. Britain now plans to generate a third of its power from wind by 2030.

It is worth being wary of the fact that a shift in demand for electricity caused by coronavirus and the expected economic stagnation might dent the momentum behind green energy projects. But then many governments want to harness their post-coronavirus recovery plans into boosting low-carbon initiatives. Under slogans such as 'build back better' and the 'Green New Deal', they are attempting to build an Asset light, profit heavy: McDonald's The frailties of the restaurant industry - expensive overexpansion resulting in high overheads; tight margins and cash flows; and a reliance on tourism - have been magnified by coronavirus. Many will not survive the repercussions, among them heavily indebted businesses and privately managed companies that never expected they would need more than a few months of rainy-day cash. Even when lockdown measures begin to ease, trade is expected to remain low for some time owing to continued social distancing measures.

Restaurant and bar owners with low operating costs and a strong ability to turn revenue into cash are the best placed to survive the ongoing challenges. And as competitors fall by the wayside and behaviour changes, they are also in the best position to keep expanding.

Fast-food behemoth McDonald's relies on an asset-light business model through which more than 90 per cent of its 39,000 restaurants are operated as franchises. This provides a relatively predictable source of cash flow in exchange for limited capital intensity - franchisees pay McDonald's rent and a percentage of their restaurant's sales as royalties while shouldering much of the required capital investment and operating costs. The margin McDonald's makes on franchises has topped 80 per cent in recent years versus less than a 20 per cent operating profit margin for company-operated restaurants. As the shift to franchises continues, the group's operating profit margin has improved from 28.1 per cent in 2015 to 43 per cent last year.

Investment in technology is boosting average customer spend. Meanwhile store formats are being rejigged to accommodate self-service terminals, mobile app order pick-ups and deliveries. Through partnerships with third-party services such as Uber Eats, 'McDelivery' sales have more than tripled over the past three years, reaching $4bn in 2019. NK A store-cupboard staple: Nestle Nestle was in a strong position before the virus struck - benefiting from geographical diversification and serious brand power. Premium goods constitute 26 per cent of Nestle's sales, but entry-level and mainstream products make up the remainder. Analysts at Barclays note that this "would be defensive if consumers down-trade". The company also has an expanding online offering - e-commerce sales soared by 29.4 per cent in the first quarter of 2020, taking this channel to more than a tenth of overall revenues for the first time ever.

Moreover, the group has continued to fine-tune its vast portfolio to focus on trend-driven nutrition, health and wellness brands. With former healthcare executive Mark Schneider at the helm, it has made more than 50 transactions in the past three years. These include the acquisition of Sweet Earth in 2017 - enhancing Nestle's position in the fastgrowing plant-based food arena - as well as the recent disposal of its US ice-cream business for $4bn.

Short-term guidance may yet change. But like the shiny sweets housed under its brand umbrella, Nestle arguably offers a 'quality street' to investors seeking diversified revenues - not to mention attractive payouts. At CHF104, the shares offer a forward dividend yield of almost 3 per cent. HC economic model that doesn't rely on so much fossil fuel usage. Coronavirus and its subsequent lockdown has revealed that we can live in a world where we are using less energy.

What's more, oil's doldrums are now showing investors a fuller picture of the opportunities for green energy investment. Crashing prices mean the economics that drove massive oil and gas projects are now gone, and renewables projects can offer equal returns with a green selling point. Consultancy Wood Mackenzie says on a pure numbers basis renewables projects now make as much sense as a new oil field. At $35 a barrel an oil project would give an average internal rate of return of 6 per cent, the same as a low-risk wind or solar project.

Looking ahead at wind turbine demand, Canaccord Genuity analysts see installed capacity rising fourfold in the next 20 years, to 115Gwp. This would cover around 60 per cent of the UK's electricity needs and largely be in the form of offshore projects in the North Sea.

Rolling with the times: Orsted Having started life as Danish Oil and Natural Gas (Dong) Energy, Orsted (Den:ORSTED) has reinvented itself over the past decade, shifting from black to green energy. The group is aiming for an average of 90 per cent of its cash profits (Ebitda) to come from long-term regulated and contracted wind power activities.

While its 6.8 gigawatts (GW) of installed offshore wind capacity is predominantly in Europe, it is expanding into the US as well as Taiwan, Japan and South Korea.

The first quarter of 2020 saw cash profits surge by a third year on year to DKr6.8bn (£810m). This was propelled by the ramp-up of power generation from newer projects and high wind speeds in Europe. Net debt of DKr27.1bn was up 50 per cent since the December year-end, but the plan to divest stakes in its wind farms could help keep this in check.

Despite the Covid-19 pandemic, the asset base remains fully operational and forward hedging provides insulation from power price volatility. Although there could be a limited impact on construction projects and some commissioning delays in the US, short-term disruption shouldn't detract from the overall investment case - the world's green energy transition will continue. NK A green leader: Vestas The comparison with oil and gas companies has always been tough for renewable project developers. For greenminded investors, there is no question who to back, but oil and gas companies have kept generalists on board with their 6 per cent-plus dividends. And with the potential rewards from oil and gas projects falling, more traditional energy companies are starting to ramp up investment in renewables.

They will be playing catch-up with turbine manufacturer Vestas (Den:VWS). Last year, the Danish company set a record for grid-connected wind capacity installed, at 11.3 GW, according to WoodMac, and has the largest slice of the pie globally, at around 17 per cent in 2019.

Its outlook for this has been affected by Covid-19, but as of 31 March it had a backlog of around (EURO)16bn in turbine orders. The company is also expected to generate around (EURO)18bn of service revenue from its currently installed turbine base. These service revenues come with very high operating margins of around 25 per cent, against an overall operating margin of 8.3 per cent in 2019. AH Ignore the theatrics: TeslaTesla's (US:TSLA) place in the automotive world is shown by its March quarter results, which includes $354m of regulatory credit sales to fellow carmakers. Tesla has a surplus of these credits and sells to other automotive companies in the US that have not hit government quotas for building electric vehicles (EVs).

Shareholders are not fussed by balance-sheet theatrics or an almost $2bn downward shift in free cash flow, to negative $895m. They even ignored Tesla chief executive Elon Musk's tweet on 1 May that the company's share price was "too high".

Looking ahead, as major carmakers catch up with Tesla in terms of EV production, it is pushing hard to maintain an advantage in range and self-driving technology. This is made easier by its control over the battery manufacturing process.

China is a crucial market for the company to maintain its leading role, because this is where around half of the world's electric cars are, according to the International Energy Agency. The company is building a new factory outside Shanghai to pump cars directly into the market, and has cut the Model 3 price specifically to keep it under the threshold for government EV subsidies. AH Bouncebackability Considering he runs a company that makes considerable revenues from travel hubs, L'Oreal's (Fra:OR) chief executive, Jean-Paul Agon, has been remarkably calm during the coronavirus pandemic. That composure perhaps stems from the fact that the French cosmetics giant is ideally placed to recover quickly: it sells via multiple channels, including a highly profitable e-commerce arm; it owns a vast range of products spanning the essential, premium and pharmaceutical branches of the cosmetics market; and its local supply chains mean it has been able to reopen in China (a key growth engine) without waiting for the rest of the world to get back on its feet.

With its imperious brand power and strong balance sheet, the company has the stability to deal with the challenges of coronavirus and it ticks the three boxes (resilience, recovery potential and cash burn) identified by ValuAnalysis as "essential in navigating the current crisis".

Wall Street has done its best to ignore the pandemic and impending recession. After a sharp sell-off in early March, the S&P 500 bounced back almost as quickly as it fell and has now returned to June 2019 levels. That resurgence has made it even harder to pick stocks. Investors are now not only facing uncertainty, but the same toppy valuations as last summer.

With these challenges in mind, stockpicking in coronavirus-infected markets has become a hotly debated topic. Should we focus on quality, or is it better to seek out value now that weaknesses have been exposed? Is 'growth at all costs' a sustainable business model, or should we be looking for well-run businesses with ample cash? The truth is, we don't know. But logic and history suggest that quality companies recover the strongest after financial crises. AJ
